 I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  India  for  the  Madhya  Pradesh  State  Roads  Project  III.  The  report  also  describes  proposed 
technical assistance (TA) for Capacity Building for Road Safety and Public–Private Participation 
(PPP)  Support,  and  if  the  Board  approves  the  proposed  loan,  I,  acting  under  the  authority 
delegated to me by the Board, will approve the TA.1 
 
The Madhya Pradesh State Roads Project III will rehabilitate and upgrade about 1,080 
2. 
kilometers  (km)  of  state  highways  in  Madhya  Pradesh  identified  under  the  state  road 
rehabilitation  program.  These  severely  deteriorated  highway  sections  are  located  in  the  very 
poor  eastern  and  west  central  parts  of  the  state.  The  project  will  involve  upgrading  existing 
roads  to  two  or  intermediate  lanes,2  strengthening  existing  pavement,  strengthening  culverts 
and  bridges,  and  constructing  new  bridges  and  cross-draining  structures.  Consulting  services 
will be provided to supervise the implementation of civil works. 
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
Under  the  country  partnership  strategy,  2009–2012, 3   the  Asian  Development  Bank 
3. 
(ADB)  supports  all  levels  of  road  sector  development  as  a  core  infrastructure  operation  to 
facilitate  sustainable  economic  growth  in  India.  The  proposed  project  is  consistent  with  the 
country  partnership  strategy’s  strategic  objectives  and  was  included  in  the  country  operations 
business plan, 2011–2013.4 
 
4. 
In  India,  road  transport  accounts  for  68%  of  freight  movement  and  87%  of  passenger 
traffic.  The  national  highways  and  the  state  highways  (i.e.,  the  secondary  road  system)  are 
unable  to  cope  with  rapid  traffic  growth;  freight  traffic  on  these  roads  has  increased  by  about 
12% per year and passenger traffic by about 8% per year over the past decade. These trends 
have led to congestion, road deterioration, and increased transport costs. State highways, which 
link  national  highways  with  district  headquarters  and  important  towns,  comprise  about  13%  of 
the road network and carry about 40% of traffic. 
 
5. 
The state highway network in Madhya Pradesh comprises 10,249 km of state highways, 
but road conditions are very poor in terms of coverage and condition and cannot cope with the 
increasing  demand  for  road  transport.  As  a  poverty  reduction  strategy,  the  Madhya  Pradesh 
government  has  encouraged  infrastructure-led  growth  in  the  last  5  years  by  successfully 
rehabilitating  about  7,400  km 5   of  state  highways  with  ADB  assistance, 6   PPP,  and  state 
resources. The gross domestic product growth was in the 5%–6% range for the last 5 years and 
is poised to reach 7% growth by 2015, closing the gap with national growth. Achieving this goal

km of state highways. 

  2 

requires continued efforts in infrastructure development initiatives by rehabilitating the remaining 
2,807 km state highways in the next few years. The government of Madhya Pradesh decided to 
rehabilitate 665 km with state resources, 771 km under PPP schemes, and requested ADB for 
possible financing of remaining 1,080 km, which are mostly in the very poor areas of the state 
(i.e., the eastern and west central areas of Madhya Pradesh) and, are not at par with the rest of 
the state in development; therefore, it is essential to improve these missing links to gain social 
and  economic  development  opportunities  from  road  networks  for  the  entire  Madhya  Pradesh 
population.  
 
6. 
ADB’s  first  involvement  in  Madhya  Pradesh’s  state  road  sector,  the  Madhya  Pradesh 
State Roads Sector Development Program, was successfully completed in 2008, with significant 
sector  reform  including  the  establishment  of  the  Madhya  Pradesh  Road  Development 
Corporation  (MPRDC)  and  its  adoption  of  best  practices  for  road  planning  and  maintenance 
systems,  financial  management,  and  public  procurement.  MPSRSP  II,  approved  in  2007,  is 
ongoing, targeting completion in December 2011. 
 
The  project  will  continue  ADB  support  for  the  development  of  the  remaining  Madhya 
7. 
Pradesh  state  highway  network  that  are  not  yet  upgraded  and  road  safety  capacity 
enhancement  of  MPRDC  to  build  upon  the  success  of  the  organization  as  an  implementation 
agency and to transform it into a full-fledged state highway agency.  Based on lessons learned 
and  achievements  of  the  previous  two  projects,  the  project  will  bring  added  value  to  the 
following  four  aspects:  (i)  minimizing  impact  of  climate  change  through  proper  engineering 
design,  and  measures  towards  "green"  highway  has  been  adopted  by  using  extensive 
vegetative control in addition to structural measures to combat erosion, and 1:7 compensatory 
reforestation which is more than the statutory requirement of 1:2; (ii) addressing road safety in 
modern  technology;  (iii)  engaging  gender  expert  to  promote  gender  awareness;  and  (iv) 
preparing  long-term  strategy  for  PPP  for  larger  private  sector  participation  in  road  network 
development and maintenance. 
 
B. 
 
8. 
The  long-term  impact  of  the  project  will  be  accelerated  economic  growth  in  Madhya 
Pradesh. The immediate project outcome will be more efficient, sustainable transport operations 
of the state highway network. 
 
C. 
 
9. 
The project outputs will be (i) about 1,080 km of state highways identified under the state 
road  rehabilitation  program  rehabilitated  and  upgraded  (Table  1),  and  (ii)  improved  MPRDC 
capacity for road safety.  
 
10. 
The  project  will  provide  (i)  consulting  services  to  support  implementation  of  the  civil 
works; and (ii) equipment necessary for MPRDC to enhance road safety, which include safety 
training, vehicle fitness testing, and a road accident emergency response system.

Implementation Arrangements 

 
E. 
 
The  implementation  arrangements  for  the  project  basically  follow  those  of  the  ongoing 
14. 
MPSRSP  II.  The  executing  agency  for  the  project  will  be  the  Madhya  Pradesh  government, 
acting through MPRDC. MPRDC is wholly owned by the Madhya Pradesh government and has 
been equipped with adequate capacity to implement the project. A general manager at MPRDC 
headquarters has been designated as person in charge for project implementation. MPRDC has 
seven division offices (i.e., Bhopal, Gwalior, Indore, Jabalpur, Sagar, Rewa, and Ujjain) acting 
as  project  implementation  units  (PIUs),  each  headed  by  a  divisional  manager,  which  will  be 
responsible for project road implementation in the field. Each PIU will be responsible for one to 
two  contracts,  depending  on  the  location  of  the  subprojects,  and  one  project  manager  will  be 
assigned  to  each  contract  package.  The  project  managers  will  be  delegated  with  adequate 
technical and administrative authority for expeditious project implementation. The Environmental 
and Social Cell at MPRDC headquarters, reporting to the general manager, will be responsible 
for ensuring compliance with environmental and social safeguards of project roads. MPRDC will 
engage construction supervision consultants to act as engineers for the construction contracts.

III. 

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

 
16. 
Capacity  development  TA  in  the  amount  of  $1,250,000  equivalent  is  proposed  to  be 
provided  to  further  support  the  MPRDC  initiatives  of  institutional  development,  especially  for 
road  safety  through  the  establishment  of  a  road  accident  emergency  response  system,  and 
PPP,  for  larger  private  sector  participation  in  state  highway  network  development  and 
maintenance. ADB will provide TA not exceeding the amount of $1,000,000 equivalent, and the 
Madhya Pradesh government will provide $250,000 equivalent as counterpart funds. 
 
17. 
The  TA  will  be  financed  with  a  grant  basis  from  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special 
Fund  (TASF–other  sources).  An  international  consulting  firm  will  be  recruited  by  ADB  in 
accordance with the ADB Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time). About 18 person-months of international and 64 person-months of national experts will be 
required.  Consultants  will  be  asked  to  submit  simplified  technical  proposals,  and  the  selection 
will  be  in  accordance  with  the  ADB  quality-  and  cost-based  selection  method  using  a  
quality–cost ratio of 80:20. The terms of reference for institutional development are set out in the 
PAM.  The  consultants  will  identify  the  specification  and  timing  of  other  equipment  required 
during TA implementation and conduct training and workshops as required. 
 

IV. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Technical 

 
A. 
 
The  project  was  prepared  with  the  enhanced  capacity  of  MPRDC,  which  was  gained 
18. 
through  the  previous  two  loans  and  TA  provided  for  capacity  building  (footnote  6).  MPRDC 
engaged  consultants  with  its  own  funds  to  prepare  detailed  design  documents  for  roads 
proposed  for  ADB  financing,  incorporating  ADB  requirements  of  economic,  social,  and 
environmental  studies  into  the  consultants’  terms  of  reference.  The  Madhya  Pradesh 
government  asked  ADB  for  TA  to  conduct  due  diligence  to  ensure  that  the  consultants’  work 

  5

 

  6 

Economic and Financial 

fully  complies  with  ADB  requirements.8  The  engineering  design  was  prepared  to  avoid  or  to 
minimize land acquisition as well as social and environmental impacts, and to take road safety 
into account. In addition, advance actions have been taken to ensure that the construction can 
commence early. All of these measures have improved project readiness and will mitigate the 
risk of delay. 
 
B. 
 
An  economic  evaluation  of  the  project  was  conducted  by  comparing  the  MPRDC  and 
19. 
user costs with and without the project over a specific period. The evaluation was carried out for 
each of the 15 project road sections using the Highway Development and Management (HDM-
4)  Model.  These  sections  are  in  poor  to  very  poor  condition.  The  proposed  improvements 
include  rehabilitation  and  widening,  and  the  principal  benefits  expected  from  the  proposed 
upgrading are in terms of savings in vehicle operating costs and travel time. The traffic demand 
forecast for all project roads was made based on data available on vehicle growth, GDP growth, 
the  elasticity  of  transport  growth  to  GDP  growth,  and  the  economic  and  population  growth 
outlook for the analysis period. 
 
20. 
The  estimated  economic  internal  rate  of  return  for  the  15  roads  varies  from  18.3%  to 
45.5%,  indicating  high  economic  rates  of  return  for  all  project  road  sections.  Sensitivity  tests 
carried out included (i) construction costs increased by 15%, (ii) no time benefits considered, (iii) 
traffic growth rates reduced by 15%, (iv) benefits decreased by 15%, and (v) a combination of (i) 
and (iv). The analysis shows that all roads have an economic internal rate of return higher than 
12% in all sensitivity tests, indicating economic viability within the range of variability anticipated. 
Overall, the project is justified in social cost–benefit terms.9

D. 
 
25.  Madhya  Pradesh  is  one  of  the  largest  and  the most  populous  states  in  India.  It  is also 
one  of  the  poorest.  About  38%  of  its  77  million  people  live  below  the  official  poverty  line, 
compared  to  about  35%  for  India  as  a  whole.  The  first  half  of  this  decade  saw  a  real  gross 
domestic product growth rate of less than 5% for the state, which was about half of the national 
growth.  Its  rural–urban  ratio  of  the  population  is  74:26.  Agriculture  is  the  main  livelihood, 
followed by allied services, trade, business, and daily wage work. 
 
In  the  poverty  and  social  assessment  survey  of  1,414  households  and  55  focus  group 
26. 
discussions in which both men and women participated, respondents stated that the project will 
provide  villages  with  better  access  and  enhanced  mobility.  Improved  connectivity  will  facilitate 
travel  to  district  headquarters,  other  local  government,  development  agencies,  health  centers, 
schools, colleges, and markets, and will also improve social networking. The project will have a 
short-term  impact  on  poverty  reduction,  as  the  rural  poor  will  be  hired  for  construction,  tree 
planting,  and  routine  maintenance  works.  These  opportunities  will  increase  the  livelihood 
opportunities  for  the  poor,  who  now  depend  largely  on  occasional,  uncertain  employment. 
Furthermore, the project will increase new economic and employment opportunities by providing 
improved  links  to  markets,  production  centers,  and  other  areas  of  economic  activities.  Better 
transport  will  help  the  rural  population  move  their  produce  faster  and  obtain  higher  profit 
margins,  as  they  will  not  depend  solely  on  local  markets  and  middlemen.  As  such,  it  is 
estimated  that  5,416,647  people  will  experience  the  economic  benefits  brought  about  by  the 
project. 11 
 
27. 
Gender. Women in the project area are largely involved in household work, cultivation, 
and  other  agricultural  activities,  including  some  employment  in  government  and  the  private 
sector.  Their  use  of  roads  ranges  from  day-to-day  household  activities  to  economic  activities, 
such  as  for  agriculture  and  marketing.  The  improved  road  conditions  and  connectivity  will 
provide better access for women and children to social services, markets, work places, higher 
levels of education, health facilities, and employment opportunities. Travel time savings due to 
enhanced road conditions will result in more time spent on productive activities, health care, and 
self-development.  
 
In the 55 focus group discussions, stakeholders expressed their concern regarding road 
28. 
safety  during  construction.  They  suggested  that  advance  notice  of  the  road  construction 
schedule, appropriate road signs, and other road safety measures be put in place during project 
implementation.  The  suggestions  have  been  incorporated  in  the  project.  Provisions  are  in  the 
bidding documents for the contractors to ensure that all civil works will comply with all applicable 
labor  laws;  not  employ  child  labor  for  construction  and  maintenance  activities;  encourage 
employment  of  the  poor,  particularly  women;  and  not  differentiate  wages  between  men  and 
women, particularly for work of equal value. To ensure that these and other gender issues are 
addressed, a gender specialist will be engaged under the construction supervision consultant to

of the project. 
 
29. 
To  further  assess  the  impact  of  ADB-funded  road  projects  (footnote  7)  on  women,  a 
separate gender impact study12 was carried out. The findings of the study show that the ADB-
funded  road  projects  brought  forth  opportunities  to  achieve  better  economic,  health,  and 
education access to the women. 
 
HIV/AIDS.  Madhya  Pradesh  is  categorized  as  a  low-prevalence  state  with  regard  to 
30. 
HIV/AIDS.  As  a  part  of  the  National  AIDS  Control  Program  of  the  National  AIDS  Control 
Organisation,  the  Madhya  Pradesh  State  AIDS  Control  Society  has  been  conducting  HIV 
sentinel surveillance and organizing AIDS awareness campaigns in the state. However, during 
focus group discussions, groups of women have expressed that there is still a need to increase 
HIV/AIDS  awareness.  The  detailed  poverty  and  social  assessment  study  carried  out  during 
project preparatory TA does not anticipate any specific risks, such as a rise in the incidence of 
HIV/AIDS,  as  the  result  of  the  project.  A  provision  has  been  kept  in  the  bidding  documents 
requiring  the  contractors  to  disseminate  information  at  worksites  on  the  risks  of  sexually 
transmitted  infections  and  HIV/AIDS  for  those  employed  during  the  construction  phase.  The 
gender  specialist  will  also  design  and  implement  an  HIV/AIDS  awareness  program  for  the 
project stakeholders. 
 
E. 
 
31. 
Environmental impact. There are no environmentally sensitive features in the proposed 
project. Hence, it has been classified as category B in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy 
Statement  (2009).  Accordingly,  initial  environmental  examination  reports  have  been  prepared 
for all 15 subprojects. All environmental management plans have been attached to the bidding 
document prior to issuance. 
  
32. 
The  main  environmental  concerns  with  respect  to  the  project  are  (i)  air  and  noise 
pollution, (ii) soil erosion of road embankments and erosion due to operation of borrow areas, (iii) 
siltation and contamination of water bodies, (iv) occupational and community health and safety, 
(v)  generation  of  construction  debris  and  domestic  waste  in  camp  sites,  (vi)  traffic  congestion 
and  other  inconveniences,  and  (vii)  poor  drainage  and  cutting  of  trees  existing  in  the  right-of-
way  (ROW).  Most  of  these  issues  are  expected  to  be  short  term  and  restricted  to  the 
construction  phase  only.  Necessary  mitigation  measures  are  proposed  in  the  environmental 
management plans to address all of these issues. The plans will be implemented mainly by the 
contractor during the construction phase and by MPRDC during operation. The Environmental 
and  Social  Cell  of  MPRDC  will  be  responsible  for  monitoring  plan  implementation  with  the 
support  from  the  PIUs  and  supervision  consultants.  A  grievance  redress  mechanism  will  be 
established within the PIUs and MPRDC, and local communities will be informed of its existence. 
 
33. 
The project has been designed with the aim of minimizing the impact of climate change. 
Such  an  impact  was  assessed  in  terms  of  increased  surface  temperature,  droughts,  and 
flooding in certain areas, as well as fewer forests and less biodiversity. Drainage structures in 
the project have been designed to accommodate increased water flow, and road embankment 
levels have been planned in accordance with flood levels. Measures toward “green” highways 
have also been adopted, such as enhancing the environmental functions of the watersheds by

 using  extensive  vegetative  control  in  addition  to  structural  measures  to  combat  erosion;  1:7 
compensatory reforestation, which is more than the statutory requirement of 1:2; preservation of 
trees through minor geometric realignments; exclusive use of native tree species in reforestation; 
and  inclusion  of  tree  survival  as  part  of  post-project  monitoring.  In  contrast  to  traditional 
approaches,  all  roadside  plantations  will  be  maintained  by  contractors  for  2  years  after 
establishment and continued by MPRDC thereafter. Accordingly, provisions have been made in 
the  bidding  document.  The  project  will  have  a  negligible  effect  on  agriculture  and  surface 
hydrology, and is likely to improve the livelihood around the project road areas in the long term. 
 
34. 
Land  acquisition  and  resettlement.  A  due  diligence  survey  was  undertaken  for  all 
project  roads,  based  on  the  detailed  designs  and  strip  plans,  to  assess  likely  involuntary 
resettlement  impacts.  Based  on  the  assessment,  there  will  be  no  land  acquisition  and 
resettlement impacts since the project is confined to the rehabilitation and upgrading of existing 
road  alignments.  The  project  roads  are  categorized  as  category  C  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Safeguard Policy Statement.  
 
35.  MPRDC adopted the approach of avoiding and minimizing impacts on land, structures, 
and  common  property  resources  through  feasible  technical  designs.  As  such,  the  project  will 
focus  on  improvement  of  roads  within  the  existing  ROW.  In  the  built-up  areas  along  some 
stretches  of  the  road  sections  that  require  a  width  of  12  meters,  resettlement  impacts  on 
roadside  structures  will  be  avoided  by  adopting  appropriate  technical  solutions,  including 
reducing  road  width,  adjusting  junction  improvement,  covering  line  drains  within  the  available 
ROW, and following existing bypasses to divert congested clusters. 
 
Impact  on  indigenous  peoples.  The  project  roads  are  categorized  as  category  C  for 
36. 
indigenous  peoples  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement.  Scheduled  tribes, 
such as the Baiga and Gonda, are present in sample project road sections. However, since the 
project  is  confined  to  rehabilitation  and  upgrading  of  existing  road  alignments,  the  social 
assessments  undertaken  have  not  brought  forth  any  adverse  impact  on  these  tribal  groups 
within  the  area  of  influence  of  the  project  roads.  According  to  the  social  assessment,  the 
improved road network is also expected to augment access to socioeconomic facilities for these 
groups. Construction will not have any adverse consequences on their socioeconomic condition 
nor lead to any disruption in the life or culture of these communities.  
 
F. 
 
37.  MPRDC  acquired  substantial  experience  under  other  ADB-funded  projects  (footnote  6) 
and  has  shown  substantial  institutional  improvement  in  preparing  this  project.  Further,  the 
lessons  learned  from  the  previous  projects  have  been  incorporated  in  the  project,  such  as  (i) 
minimizing  the  impact  of  climate  change  through  proper  engineering  design,  extensive 
vegetative control, structural measures to combat erosion, and 1:7 compensatory reforestation; 
(ii)  addressing  road  safety  in  a  better  manner  through  proper  engineering  input,  particularly 
provisions  of  safety  features  like  road  markings,  cautionary  boards,  crash  barriers,  and 
replacement  of  old  cross-drainage  structures;  and  (iii)  avoiding  land  acquisition  through 
engineering solutions and limiting rehabilitation of the state highways to the existing ROW.
